title: Mahama is passing his incompetence on to us – Ben Aryeh
text:
Source: Ghana | Multi TV | Nii Akrofi Smart-Abbey Date: 20-10-2015 Time: 05:10:27:pm Benjamin Kofi Aryeh 
The Member of Parliament for Upper Denkyira West Benjamin Kofi Aryeh says asking the public to pay more for utility is akin to asking them to pay for the incompetence of the government. 
Utility service providers have submitted proposals to the Public Utilities Regulatory Commission (PURC) for increase in tariffs of over 100 percent. 
President Mahama in an interview with Garden City radio in the Ashanti region backed the utility providers, stating that the public should pay more if it wants continuous supply of power. 
But speaking on JoyNews’ AM Show on MultiTV, Mr. Aryeh said if the President paid his own utility bills, he would not have supported an increase in tariffs. 
“The President wants the masses or the people to carry his incompetence” he told AM Talk host Roland Walker. 
“Just last year, you slapped over 80 percent increment [on tariffs] and the people just swallowed it, granted that you claim you brought inflation down to 17 and half percent. You increased workers salary also by 10 percent. So why the over 100 percent increase after the people have paid 80 percent last year?” he asked. 
He argued that “if anything at all, the margin of increase should have marched the inflationary increases in this case 17.5 percent, so why is the President asking for over 100 percent increment?” 
He criticized the President’s management of the economy saying it is partly to blame for the over 100 percent increase. 
“The two major variables that go into the determination of utility bills are foreign exchange issues and inflation. If the President and his economic management team are not able to manage this economy well and you see your currency depreciating for [which] reason whatever was raised for ECG and VRA to import their inputs the value of whatever was given to them has been devalued because of your incompetence, do we have to suffer for it or do you rather have to improve on how you manage our economy?” 
According to him, but for the depreciation of the cedi, perhaps this 100 percent increase would not have arisen. “Imagine if the cedi had been stable … so he’s passing his incompetence to us, that is why we have to say no”. 
He said increases in utility and taxes without a corresponding increase in salaries create a fertile ground for corruption. 
“The President thinks the easiest way to raise money to resolve this issue is to go to the consumers forgetting that the consumers also have a limit as to how far they can go. Have you increased their salaries by that much, if you haven’t where are they going to get the difference from? These are some of the things that lead to corruption. 
“…Imagine his salary is increased by 10 percent and all these things are increased beyond 10 percent how would that person bridge that gap? The person may end up finding money from wherever sources to make up for the difference. That is what is making the fight against corruption a lot more difficult for all of us in this country because we only look at collecting taxes from the people without thinking about where they will get the resources to pay for these things” he argued.
